body: @sagaragrawal13 Can you try to install the latest one? Please let me know you still met the error.

No, since argmax(x, axis=1) will return the maximum column indices along each row. This is not what I want. I want that given a column i, the indices of the rows, which have their maximum values at column i. These are quite different things.

@thirdwing  Sure. I will try and let you know. 

Thanks for quick replies. :+1:
just submitted one...

@chinakook, thanks for your sharing. I figure out there is a major problem resulting the performance gap: I use the mean_value incorrectly due to the order difference of caffe's mean_value (BGR), and mxnet's mean_value (RGB). After I change the mean_value, the results in mxnet looks better. But they are not the same.
caffe:
![frankfurt_000000_016286_leftimg8bit_col](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20036855/27205998-50c9de9c-5202-11e7-82f5-bb9252db12a1.png)

mxnet:
![seg](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20036855/27205988-3d5498d4-5202-11e7-9440-15cef141985e.png)

The details are still somehow different. Furthermore, I checked the mIOU of validation set of Cityscapes dataset, the mIOU in mxnet is 0.8% lower than caffe. I may try to see if this is caused by the eps.
@mli can you check?

I think by default, people only need to store the evaluation metrics on validation set, not on training set.

For this problem, I would hack by manually iterate training and validation set.
```
    for batch in train_iter:
        labels = batch.label[0].asnumpy()
        mod.forward(batch, is_train=True)
        mod.update_metric(metric, batch.label)
        mod.backward()
        mod.update()
        pred = mod.get_outputs()
        # do evaluation based on labels and pred

    for batch in val_iter:
        labels = batch.label[0].asnumpy()
        mod.forward(batch, is_train=True)
        mod.update_metric(metric, batch.label)
        mod.backward()
        mod.update()
        pred = mod.get_outputs()
        # do evaluation based on labels and pred
```

And after all, remember to reset train_iter and val_iter by `train_iter.reset()` and `val_iter.reset()`.
fixed and rebased

CPU pkg for Windows and OSX:

```r
install.packages("mxnet", repos="https://s3.amazonaws.com/mxnet-r/")
```

GPU pkg for Windows:

```r
install.packages("mxnet", repos="https://s3.amazonaws.com/mxnet-r/GPU")
```

The unfortunately high abs tolerance is due to that [fmod is not sticking to double precision](https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=48140). So in some cases the error margin can be quite high. For example:
```
found precision problem
a: [ 0.47467953]
b: [ 0.47467954]
a hex: 46481b422661de3f
b hex: f4035e4d2661de3f
in baseline(a, b): [ 0.47467953]
in symbol(a, b): [ 0.]
diff: [ 0.47410485]
```

@JeanKossaifi Could you take a look again?

I renamed to `row_wise_kronecker()` which is the calculation routine, and added `krprod()` which is a wrapper of call to `row_wise_kronecker()` on transposed matrices.
Lint and default layout should be fixed now.
@flice Yes, it keeps accuracy 0.00 at first, and about 2 epoch later, it will begin convergen, if I If I remember rightly .

Close this issue.
Solve this problem, pls update accuracy compute method according batch size.
Error occured when compute accuracy.

@chinakook I have tried your suggestions, such as turn off the bn layer's cudnn, comment out 'eps_correction'(Ln149,Ln152) as follows:
Ln149            # eps_correction = eps_caffe - eps_symbol
Ln150            # Fill parameters
Ln151            aux_params[mean_name][:] = mean * rescale_factor
Ln152            aux_params[var_name][:] = var * rescale_factor # + eps_correction

Actually I am not sure where to set the mod.bind for_training=True. Currently I choose to set it in convert_model.py:
model.bind(for_training=True,data_shapes=[('data', tuple(input_dim))])

Currently, I still get slightly worse result in mxnet. Would you please give me some other comments? Any help will be appreciated.
change gcc and g++ to clang and clang++, is ok
new version is ok

```r
setRepositories(addURLs = c(CRANxtras = "https://s3.amazonaws.com/mxnet-r/"))
install.packages("mxnet")
```

changing line 78 of dmlc-core/tracker/dmlc_tracker/ssh.py
to
`prog = get_env(pass_envs) + ' cd ' + working_dir.replace(" ", "\ ") + '; ' + (' '.join(args.command))`
makes it work, 
but not sure it it's the best place for this replace

```r
cran <- getOption("repos")
cran["dmlc"] <- "https://s3.amazonaws.com/mxnet-r/"
options(repos = cran)
install.packages("mxnet")
```

@yzou2 Sorry, I got a mistake! Actually, you should set "use_global_stats: true" in prototxt of Caffe and write "model.bind(for_training=False,data_shapes=[('data', tuple(input_dim))])" in your own mxnet test script(not the convert_model.py). As a result, Both Caffe and mxnet can use the constant BatchNorm momentums learned in the previous training stage(not the momentums calculated by the input image) in a inference case. I want to know how do you write your test code ?
Another key point is that the Caffe use BGR inputs but the mxnet use RGB inputs, you also need to swap the rgb planes.
@yuconglin Yeah I simply re-installed it and it worked. Thanks!
half2_t needs special treatment as its comparison is not straightforward. Made pr to mshadow for mod on half2_t and needs mshadow#261 to work.

I met same problem when training DeepID,  Train-accuracy Between 0.4 and 0.6ã€‚How did you solve the problem? The data set I use is webface ....

python train.py \
    --train-path=/data/mxnet/ssd/training_filelist.rec \
    --train-list=/data/mxnet/ssd/training_filelist.lst \
    --val-path=/data/mxnet/ssd/validation_filelist.rec \

    --num-class=$num_classes \

    --data-shape=512

@chao1224 Thank you so much!
Cub now points to dmlc/cub. You need to re-clone

Hi, @shivonkar 

Just as I have said in the email, I don't think this is possible since we never store this info in the model.

The problem seems that Jenkin's setup is highly efficient and uses tons of cached data. And this does not take the Makefile changes into account. So when I'm changing the Makefile (to see whether lapack is now detected), it will not recompile libmxnet (just uses the version it did build once for the same commit), so the potentially different compile flag has no effect. 
Let me try to get this resolved and will let you know.

* added linear solver for positive, semi-definite l.h.s matrix A (`MXNET_LAPACK_posv`), which handles both row-major & column-major matrices for the r.h.s matrix B
* added the Moore-Penrose pseudo inverse of the Khatri-Rao product

In most times, the default layout for DataDesc is 'NCHW' or 'NTC'. And, if the `layout` given to `get_batch_axis` is null, it will return 0 which is just the default batch axis. If your layout is not `N...`, set the layout attribute into op by yourself. Also, `concat` can concatenate those tensors different on the batch axis.
```
def get_batch_axis(layout):
        """Get the dimension that corresponds to the batch size.

        When data parallelism is used, the data will be automatically split and
        concatenated along the batch-size dimension. Axis can be -1, which means
        the whole array will be copied for each data-parallelism device.

        Parameters
        ----------
        layout : str
            layout string. For example, "NCHW".

        Returns
        -------
        int
            An axis indicating the batch_size dimension.
        """
        if layout is None:
            return 0
        return layout.find('N')
```

```
def concatenate(arrays, axis=0, always_copy=True):
    """DEPRECATED, use ``concat`` instead

    Parameters
    ----------
    arrays : list of `NDArray`
        Arrays to be concatenate. They must have identical shape except
        the first dimension. They also must have the same data type.
    axis : int
        The axis along which to concatenate.
    always_copy : bool
        Default `True`. When not `True`, if the arrays only contain one
        `NDArray`, that element will be returned directly, avoid copying.

    Returns
    -------
    NDArray
        An `NDArray` that lives on the same context as `arrays[0].context`.
    """
    assert isinstance(arrays, list)
    assert len(arrays) > 0
    assert isinstance(arrays[0], NDArray)

    if not always_copy and len(arrays) == 1:
        return arrays[0]

    shape_axis = arrays[0].shape[axis]
    shape_rest1 = arrays[0].shape[0:axis]
    shape_rest2 = arrays[0].shape[axis+1:]
    dtype = arrays[0].dtype
    for arr in arrays[1:]:
        shape_axis += arr.shape[axis]
        assert shape_rest1 == arr.shape[0:axis]
        assert shape_rest2 == arr.shape[axis+1:]
        assert dtype == arr.dtype
    ret_shape = shape_rest1 + (shape_axis,) + shape_rest2
    ret = empty(ret_shape, ctx=arrays[0].context, dtype=dtype)

    idx = 0
    begin = [0 for _ in ret_shape]
    end = list(ret_shape)
    for arr in arrays:
        if axis == 0:
            ret[idx:idx+arr.shape[0]] = arr
        else:
            begin[axis] = idx
            end[axis] = idx+arr.shape[axis]
            # pylint: disable=no-member,protected-access
            _internal._crop_assign(ret, arr, out=ret,
                                   begin=tuple(begin),
                                   end=tuple(end))
            # pylint: enable=no-member,protected-access
        idx += arr.shape[axis]

    return ret
```
